Several New Bedford beaches closed to swimming

Thursday
Jul17,2014at11:00AM Jul17,2014at11:02AM

NEW BEDFORD Several sections of East Beach and West Beach have been closed to swimming today by order of the Health Department due to elevated bacteria levels.

NEW BEDFORD Several sections of East Beach and West Beach have been closed to swimming today by order of the Health Department due to elevated bacteria levels.

On East Rodney French Boulevard, the Tower 1, Tower 4 and Davys Locker sections are closed to swimming. On West Rodney French Boulevard, Kids Beach, J Beach and Squid Beach are closed.

A map of those sections is available online at http://nbcity.newbedford-ma.gov/health/maps/BeachMaster.htm.

According to the Health Department, water testing indicates that the water quality is acceptable for swimming at North 400 and South 400 beach on the West Rodney French, as well as the Tabor Park South Beach.

Water at all city beaches will be tested daily until water quality levels are acceptable and swimming can resume at all sections. For additional information the New Bedford Health Department can be contacted at 508-991-6199.

JONATHAN CARVALHO

                        if( serviceID != 0 ){

                                bloxHasSubscription = true;
                                return false;
                            }
                        }else{

                            return false;
                        }
                    });
                }

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>WAYNESBORO, Pa.  The Waynesboro Borough Authority made its customers aware Wednesday of bacteria found in water testing.</p></div><div class="subscriber-preview"><p>The borough authority manages the public water and sewer lines within Waynesboro and a portion of the surrounding area.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"In July, tests showed coliform bacteria in the water. Fifteen samples were collected, and two of these samples tested positive for coliform bacteria," said a message distributed through an automated phone call.</p></div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Both samples came from the same outside faucet, Waynesboro Borough Authority Chairman Jon Fleagle said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Samples from neighboring properties were clean, as was a subsequent one taken from the problem faucet, Fleagle said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The coliform found could be naturally present in the environment and was not a variety of greater concern, such as fecal coliform or E. coli, according to a written statement from the authority.</p></div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"The water is safe, fine," Fleagle said. "I drink it every day."</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The borough has eight sampling sites, Borough Manager Lloyd Hamberger said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"It could've been a sampling problem. It could've been a problem in a lab," Fleagle said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>"It doesn't mean the water is bad or the (Department of Environmental Protection) would've required us to do a boil-water notice," Hamberger said.</p></div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>
<div class="share-container content-below" data-subscription-required-remove="">

    "name": "Boil-water advisory issued for part of Buckner",
    "headline": "Boil-water advisory issued for part of Buckner",
    "articleBody": "Buckner issued a boil-water advisory late Wednesday for part of the city due to a line replacement.City officials said the order affects homes in the 300 block of South Osage street, south to the railroad tracks and west to Vernon Street.Customers in the area should boil all drinking and cooking water for three minutes before using it.The boil-water advisory will be in effect until Saturday, officials said.",

<strong class="dateline">BUCKNER, Mo. </strong> <p>Buckner issued a boil-water advisory late Wednesday for part of the city due to a line replacement.<br/></p><p>City officials said the order affects homes in the 300 block of South Osage street, south to the railroad tracks and west to Vernon Street.</p><div class="article-content--body-wrapper-side-floater ">

<div class="ad-container or-halfpage" data-loc="btf" data-type="rectangle"></div>
<div class="ad-label">Advertisement</div>
</div>
<!-- blocks/ad.twig -->
</div>
<p>Customers in the area should boil all drinking and cooking water for three minutes before using it.</p><p>The boil-water advisory will be in effect until Saturday, officials said.</p>
</div>
</div>

Gouldsboro State Park beach closed for high bacteria levels

Wednesday
Jul16,2014at3:30PM Jul16,2014at3:36PM

Gouldsboro State Park in Wayne County became the second local state park to close their lake to swimming this week because of high bacteria levels on Wednesday.

While the beach is closed to swimmers, the park is open for all other forms of recreation, park officials said in a press release.

Beltzville State Park, in Carbon County, has dealt with intermittent closures since the beginning of the month because of high bacteria counts. They recently revealed that goose droppings are to blame.

Officials at Gouldsboro State Park did not have details on what caused the high bacteria levels.

From DCNR:
The Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) closed the beach at Gouldsboro State Park in Wayne County to swimming effective Wednesday, July 16, 2014, because of high
bacterial counts in water samples taken on July 14, 2014.

The beach will remain closed as a precaution until acceptable water sample results are received. DCNR has posted signs at the beach.

Gouldsboro State Park is part of the Tobyhanna State Park Complex.

Swimming activities are available at Tobyhanna State Park beach as well as picnicking, fishing, boating, hiking and camping, which will proceed as usual.

For more information about Pennsylvanias 120 state parks, visit the DCNR website at www.dcnr.state.pa.us.

<meta content='SEATTLE -- Dash Point State Park beach in King County and Twanoh State Park beach in Mason County were both closed to swimming Tuesday because of high levels of fecal bacteria in the water, the state Department of Ecology announced.

"Contact with fecal contaminated waters can result in gastroenteritis, skin rashes, upper respiratory infections, and other illnesses. Children and the elderly may be more vulnerable to waterborne illnesses," the department said.' property="og:description"/>

<h1 class="entry-title">Yuck! Two local beaches closed to swimming due to high levels of fecalbacteria</h1>
<div class="entry-meta clearfix">
<span class="posted-time">Posted 5:41 PM, July 15, 2014, by <a class="author url fn" href="http://q13fox.com/author/tribrobmackay/" rel="author" title="Posts by Q13 FOX News Staff">Q13 FOX News Staff</a></span> </div>

Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.</div> <article class="post-114050 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" id="post-114050">
<div class="entry-content">
<div class="wp-caption aligncenter" id="attachment_54303" style="max-width: 650px"><a href="http://tribkcpq.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/dash-point.jpeg?quality=85&strip=all"><img alt="dash point" class="size-full wp-image-54303" src="http://tribkcpq.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/dash-point.jpeg?quality=85&strip=all&w=770"/></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Dash Point State Park beach in King County</p></div>
<p>SEATTLE  Dash Point State Park beach in King County and Twanoh State Park beach in Mason County were both closed to swimming Tuesday because of high levels of fecal bacteria in the water, the state Department of Ecology announced.</p>
<p>Contact with fecal contaminated waters can result in gastroenteritis, skin rashes, upper respiratory infections, and other illnesses. Children and the elderly may be more vulnerable to waterborne illnesses, the department said.</p>
<p>Stay updated about water quality at your beaches by keeping up with the Ecology Department on its blog <a href="http://ecologywa.blogspot.com/search/label/Fecal%20matters"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">Fecal Matters</span></a>, on <a href="http://www.facebook.com/WABEACH"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">Facebook</span></a>, or join its <a href="http://listserv.wa.gov/cgi-bin/wa?A0=BEACH"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">listserv</span></a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</div>

<meta content='SEATTLE -- Dash Point State Park beach in King County and Twanoh State Park beach in Mason County were both closed to swimming Tuesday because of high levels of fecal bacteria in the water, the state Department of Ecology announced.

<h1 class="entry-title">Yuck! Two local beaches closed to swimming due to high levels of fecalbacteria</h1>
<div class="entry-meta clearfix">
<span class="posted-time">Posted 5:41 PM, July 15, 2014, by <a class="author url fn" href="http://q13fox.com/author/tribrobmackay/" rel="author" title="Posts by Q13 FOX News Staff">Q13 FOX News Staff</a></span> </div>

<div class="article-archived">This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.</div> <article class="post-114050 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" id="post-114050">
<div class="entry-content">
<div class="wp-caption aligncenter" id="attachment_54303" style="max-width: 650px"><a href="http://tribkcpq.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/dash-point.jpeg?quality=85&strip=all"><img alt="dash point" class="size-full wp-image-54303" src="http://tribkcpq.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/dash-point.jpeg?quality=85&strip=all&w=770"/></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Dash Point State Park beach in King County</p></div>
<p>SEATTLE  Dash Point State Park beach in King County and Twanoh State Park beach in Mason County were both closed to swimming Tuesday because of high levels of fecal bacteria in the water, the state Department of Ecology announced.</p>
<p>Contact with fecal contaminated waters can result in gastroenteritis, skin rashes, upper respiratory infections, and other illnesses. Children and the elderly may be more vulnerable to waterborne illnesses, the department said.</p>
<p>Stay updated about water quality at your beaches by keeping up with the Ecology Department on its blog <a href="http://ecologywa.blogspot.com/search/label/Fecal%20matters"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">Fecal Matters</span></a>, on <a href="http://www.facebook.com/WABEACH"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">Facebook</span></a>, or join its <a href="http://listserv.wa.gov/cgi-bin/wa?A0=BEACH"><span style="color:#3d81ee;">listserv</span></a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
</div>

	// Expando Mode: start small, then auto-resize on first click + text length
	jQuery( '#comment-form-identity' ).hide();
	jQuery( '#comment-form-subscribe' ).hide();
	jQuery( '#commentform .form-submit' ).hide();

	comment.css( { 'height':'10px' } ).one( 'focus', function() {
		var timer = setInterval( HighlanderComments.resizeCallback, 10 )

		jQuery( '#comment-form-identity' ).slideDown();
		jQuery( '#comment-form-subscribe' ).slideDown();
		jQuery( '#commentform .form-submit' ).slideDown();
	});
}
jQuery(document).ready( highlander_expando_javascript );

<div class="card-body">

        Concord teacher to be honored</a></h3>
</div>
<div class="card-lead">
<p>A Concord West Side Elementary School teacher will be recognized Saturday during halftime of the Big Ten Football Championship in Indianapolis for a project she and her students developed to help reduce waste and improve efficiency within the schools drinking water system.</p>

<div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"></div><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">Due to a water main leak along West Market Street, homes and businesss along West Market from Williams Street to Main Street are under a "boil water order" immediately.</div>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/goshennews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/goshennews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">As a precautionary measure anyone living in th is area is asked to boil their drinking and cooking water for 5 minutes before using. Continue to boil water unlil advised that the "boil order" has been lifted.</div><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">The utility is proceeding as quickly as possible to correct the leak situation and will proceed with bacteriological samples, as soon as possible, city officials said.</div>

                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }

                });

    American Water issues Boil Water Notice for Fort Hood

    FORT HOOD, TX, UNITED STATES

    07.14.2014

    Courtesy Story

    Fort Hood Public Affairs Office

    Subscribe
    9

    FORT HOOD, Texas -- American Water, Fort Hood's water utility supplier, has issued a "Boil Water Alert" for customers in all housing areas, all of main cantonment of Fort Hood, including CRDAMC due to the loss of potable water supply from Fort Hood's water supplier.

    The "Boil Water Notice" order will remain in effect until officials from American Water receive confirmation from laboratory analysis that the water quality meets drinking water standards.

    For more information contact:
    Fort Hood Public Affairs Office
    www.forthoodpresscenter.com
    (254) 286-5139
    1001 761st Tank Battalion Ave
    Suite W105
    Fort Hood, TX 76544
    query@forthoodpresscenter.com

Vicksburg issues water boil advisory after water main breaks

Print Email
Tom Haroldson | Special to MLive By Tom Haroldson | Special to MLive The Kalamazoo Gazette
on July 13, 2014 at 8:38 PM, updated July 13, 2014 at 8:41 PM
comments

VICKSBURG, MI Vicksburg residents are under a boil order advisory after a water main ruptured in the village.

A water boil advisory has been issued for Vicksburg residents.File photo

Ken Schippers, Vicksburg village manager and director of public works, said that the water main break means residents should boil water at least 20 minutes before consumption or food preparation, and avoid use of water whenever possible until further notice.

The village will have more information on Monday.

Lake Country beach closed due to water quality issues

Howard Alexander - News Editor
Signs are up at the beach in Pioneer Park in Oyama warning swimmers not to take dip in Kalamalka Lake.
Image Credit: Global Okanagan (with permission)
July 12, 2014 - 10:48 AM

LAKE COUNTRY The beach in Pioneer Park has been closed due to water quality concerns.

Signs are up warning swimmers not to swim at the Kalamalka Lake beach in Oyama.

Parents with children enrolled with the District of Lake Country Parks, Rec and Culture Department received an email on Friday advising lessons would be held at the beach at Kaloya Park instead.

Pioneer Beach has had water quality problems before. Just last summer the beach was closed by the Interior Health Authority when water tests came back from the lab with unacceptable levels of E. Coli.

According to guidelines on water quality issued by Health Canada there are a number of ways water can become contaminated with the E. Coli.

The water may be contaminated with fecal material from discharged sewage, storm water runoff from agriculture or urban areas, and wild or domesticated animals and even through fecal shedding by swimmers themselves.

Fecal shedding by swimmers is another way to say pooping in the water.

The email from the district says the poor water quality was discovered on Friday afternoon.

Its impossible to say if any other beaches are dealing with water quality issues this weekend because Interior Healths weekly beach water quality ratings are out of date. They were last updated on July 4.

To contact the reporter for this story, email Adam Proskiw at aproskiw@infotelnews.ca or call 250-718-0428. To contact the editor, email mjones@infotelnews.ca or call 250-718-2724.

This story was updated at 12:38 p.m., Sunday, July 13 to add a new picture.

Westside Jacksonville residents asked to boil water

JEA: Advisory is a result of a weather-related incident, subsequent repairs

By Marques White - Reporter
Posted: 12:08 PM, July 12, 2014 Updated: 12:08 PM, July 12, 2014

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A "weather-related" water-main break prompted a precautionary boil water advisory for certain JEA customers living south of 103rd Street on Jacksonville's Westside, according to a press release.

This precautionary advisory was issued Saturday morning as a result the break and subsequent repairs.

The boil water advisory affects only those customers within these boundaries:

  • 103rd Street on the north
  • Parman Road on the south
  • Smithtorian Drive to the east
  • Connie Jean Road on the west


The JEA said customers should bring water to a rolling boil for a minimum of one minute prior to usingfor drinking, food preparation or cooking.

JEA recommends customers flush water lines for three minutes after water returns inorder to remove any air and possible sediments from the lines.

The advisory will remain in place until the problem has been corrected and two consecutivedays of satisfactory bacteriological results have been obtained, according to the press release. Affected customers will benotified when the precautionary advisory is lifted.

<header>
<strong class="breadcrumb"><a href="/long-island">Long Island</a><a href="/long-island/nassau">Nassau</a></strong>
<h1>3 Nassau beaches closed because of bacterial concerns</h1>
</header>
</div>
<div class="gut">
<section class="contentWell">
<div class="mediaCell" id="topm">
<img alt="Seagulls cruise in formation off Philip B. Healey" height="431" src="https://cdn.newsday.com/polopoly_fs/1.8403662.1426625922!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_768/image.jpg" width="768"/>
</div>
<p class="caption">
	 Seagulls cruise in formation off Philip B. Healey Beach off Florence Avenue in Massapequa.                 Photo Credit: Newsday/David L. Pokress      </p>
<div class="byline">
<div>
<strong>By ROBERT BRODSKY</strong>         	<a href="mailto:robert.brodsky@newsday.com?subject=newsday.com">robert.brodsky@newsday.com</a> <time datetime="2014-07-12T12:37:00-05:00" itemprop="datePublished">Updated July 12, 2014 12:37 PM</time>
</div>
</div>
<div class="sshare">
<a class="printBtn" onclick="window.print();"> Print</a>
<a class="commentBtn " href="#"> See Comments</a>
<input id="checkbox_toggle" type="checkbox"/>
<label for="checkbox_toggle">
<a class="tog">Share <i class="fa fa-share-alt"></i></a>
</label>
<div class="simpleShare">
<a class="fb" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-facebook"></i>Share</a>
<a class="tw" data-mention="@Newsday" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-twitter"></i> Tweet</a>
<a class="gp" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-google-plus"></i> Share</a>
<a class="env" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-envelope"></i> Email</a>
</div>
</div>
<p>Three Nassau beaches -- Biltmore and Philip Healey in Massapequa and Morgan beach in Glen Cove -- remained closed on Saturday because of elevated levels of bacteria, according to the county's Department of Health.</p>
<p>Biltmore and Philip Healey beaches have been closed since July 9 while Saturday was the first day Morgan has been closed.</p>
<p>The rest of the county's beaches that are operating during the 2014 season are open, the department said.</p>

</noscript>
<img alt="Aidan Masterson, 7, and sister, Riley, 5, of" class="ph" data-src="https://cdn.newsday.com/polopoly_fs/1.8902085.1426623371!/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/landscape_768/image.JPG" height="431" src="/img/loaders/landscape.png" width="768"/>
<span class="btn stk"><strong>SEE PHOTOS</strong>
       		Long Island beach scenes
			</span>
</a>
</figure>
</aside>
</div>
<p>Members of the public can get updated recorded information on beach openings and closures by calling 516-227-9700.</p>

<main class="container">
<article>
<div class="sticky">
<div class="top fullBanner ad">
<div class="adBanner"></div>
</div>
<header>
<strong class="breadcrumb"><a href="/long-island">Long Island</a><a href="/long-island/nassau">Nassau</a></strong>
<h1>3 Nassau beaches closed because of bacterial concerns</h1>
</header>
</div>
<div class="gut">
<section class="contentWell">
<div class="mediaCell" id="topm">
<img alt="Seagulls cruise in formation off Philip B. Healey" height="431" src="https://cdn.newsday.com/polopoly_fs/1.8403662.1426625922!/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_768/image.jpg" width="768"/>
</div>
<p class="caption">
	 Seagulls cruise in formation off Philip B. Healey Beach off Florence Avenue in Massapequa.                 Photo Credit: Newsday/David L. Pokress      </p>
<div class="byline">
<div>
<strong>By ROBERT BRODSKY</strong>         	<a href="mailto:robert.brodsky@newsday.com?subject=newsday.com">robert.brodsky@newsday.com</a> <time datetime="2014-07-12T12:37:00-05:00" itemprop="datePublished">Updated July 12, 2014 12:37 PM</time>
</div>
</div>
<div class="sshare">
<a class="printBtn" onclick="window.print();"> Print</a>
<a class="commentBtn " href="#"> See Comments</a>
<input id="checkbox_toggle" type="checkbox"/>
<label for="checkbox_toggle">
<a class="tog">Share <i class="fa fa-share-alt"></i></a>
</label>
<div class="simpleShare">
<a class="fb" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-facebook"></i>Share</a>
<a class="tw" data-mention="@Newsday" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-twitter"></i> Tweet</a>
<a class="gp" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-google-plus"></i> Share</a>
<a class="env" href=""><i aria-hidden="true" class="fa fa-envelope"></i> Email</a>
</div>
</div>
<p>Three Nassau beaches -- Biltmore and Philip Healey in Massapequa and Morgan beach in Glen Cove -- remained closed on Saturday because of elevated levels of bacteria, according to the county's Department of Health.</p>
<p>Biltmore and Philip Healey beaches have been closed since July 9 while Saturday was the first day Morgan has been closed.</p>
<p>The rest of the county's beaches that are operating during the 2014 season are open, the department said.</p>
<div id="rlm_1_imagegallery">
<aside class="mediaCell">
<figure class="pg" data-feed="/json/travel/long-island-getaways/beaches/long-island-beach-scenes-1.2214893?view=galleryFeed" data-gallery-title="Long Island beach scenes">
<a href="/travel/long-island-getaways/beaches/long-island-beach-scenes-1.2214893">
<noscript>
<img alt="Aidan Masterson, 7, and sister, Riley, 5, of" class="ph" height="431" src="https://cdn.newsday.com/polopoly_fs/1.8902085.1426623371!/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/landscape_768/image.JPG" width="768"/>
</noscript>
<img alt="Aidan Masterson, 7, and sister, Riley, 5, of" class="ph" data-src="https://cdn.newsday.com/polopoly_fs/1.8902085.1426623371!/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/landscape_768/image.JPG" height="431" src="/img/loaders/landscape.png" width="768"/>

Westside Jacksonville residents asked to boil water

JEA: Advisory is a result of a weather-related incident, subsequent repairs

By Marques White - Reporter
Posted: 12:08 PM, July 12, 2014 Updated: 12:08 PM, July 12, 2014

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A "weather-related" water-main break prompted a precautionary boil water advisory for certain JEA customers living south of 103rd Street on Jacksonville's Westside, according to a press release.

This precautionary advisory was issued Saturday morning as a result the break and subsequent repairs.

The boil water advisory affects only those customers within these boundaries:

  • 103rd Street on the north
  • Parman Road on the south
  • Smithtorian Drive to the east
  • Connie Jean Road on the west


The JEA said customers should bring water to a rolling boil for a minimum of one minute prior to usingfor drinking, food preparation or cooking.

JEA recommends customers flush water lines for three minutes after water returns inorder to remove any air and possible sediments from the lines.

The advisory will remain in place until the problem has been corrected and two consecutivedays of satisfactory bacteriological results have been obtained, according to the press release. Affected customers will benotified when the precautionary advisory is lifted.
